author: Mackenzie Aucker
title: New Wawa opens in Williamsport
text:
WILLIAMSPORT, Pa. â€” About 300 people lined up outside in the bitter coldâ€”all to make their way into the first Wawa to open in the Williamsport area. Some came as early as 5 a.m. to be first in line to receive free coffee and a t-shirt.
"I love Wawa, and I've always grown up with Wawa, and I think it's way better than Sheetz. I just can't wait to have this one open finally," said John Swider, Philadelphia.
Customers tell Newswatch 16 they're happy to have a staple from their hometowns right in Central Pennsylvania.
"I came from New Jersey a very long time ago here, and I lived near Wawa's all my life up until I moved here; we don't have one, and I'm so excited," said Bert Hall, Williamsport.
"I used to go to Wawa in Jersey every morning, and I was happy to see it come here, so I came here, I got my coffee, I got my t-shirt, I can come here every morning now," said William Colon, Williamsport.
"Whether it's folks who have moved from the Philadelphia area or folks who travel maybe from Central Pennsylvania over to New Jersey have seen our stores and just how much how they would love to have a Wawa in their community," said Alyson Mucha, Wawa Public Relations Lead.
The Wawa in Williamsport marks the company's sixth location in Central Pennsylvania.
"The reception in Williamsport and in the Central Pennsylvania market overall has been so welcoming, and it feels like we fit right in with Williamsport, and Williamsport fits right in with us," said Mucha
Over the next five years, Wawa plans to open 40 locations in Central Pennsylvania.

author: AsiaNews.it
title: Pope on Palestine and Israel: 'No to war. Yes to dialogue'
text:
Pope on Palestine and Israel: â€˜No to war. Yes to dialogueâ€™
From the Vatican new call for peace in the Middle East. But also a thought for the â€˜tormented Ukraineâ€™ that â€˜suffers so muchâ€™. Best wishes to the brothers and sisters of the Orthodox Churches for Easter celebrated today, according to the Julian calendar. â€˜May the Risen Lord comfort the communities that are in trialâ€™.
Vatican City (AsiaNews) - â€˜I affectionatley send my best wishes to the brothers and sisters of the Orthodox Churches and some Eastern Catholic Churches who are celebrating Holy Easter today, according to the Julian calendar,â€™ began the Angelus address of Pope Francis this Sunday, delievered from the window of the Vatican Apostolic Palace this morning immediately after the recitation of the Regina Caeli prayer.
â€˜May the Risen Lord fill all communities with joy and peace and comfort those who are in trial. Happy Easter to them!â€™ The wish was greeted by the crowd gathered in St. Peter's with applause; a holiday celebrated six weeks after Catholic Easter, which follows the Gregorian calendar.
There was no shortage of appeals for peace. â€˜Please, let us continue to pray for the tormented Ukraine. It suffers so much,' the Pontiff said. A suffering thought was also addressed to the Middle East.
This was followed by a request to pray also for â€˜Palestine and Israelâ€™. â€˜May there be peaceâ€™: these were the words greeted by further roaring applause.
â€˜So that the dialogue between them may be strengthened and bear good fruit. No to war. Yes to dialogue,' he said. The Pontiff then recalled the population of the State of Rio Grande do Sul, in Brazil, hit by violent floods. â€˜I assure my prayers,â€™ he said, â€˜that the Lord may welcome the dead, comfort their families, and those who had to leave their homes. Thousands - about 70,000 - have been displaced.
Before the recitation of the Regina Caeli Marian prayer, Pope Francis commented on the Gospel of the Day (Jn 15:9-17), in which Jesus speaks to the disciples saying â€˜You are my friendsâ€™.
He continued: â€˜This I command you: that you love one anotherâ€™. The Pontiff elaborated on the meaning of being called â€˜friendsâ€™ instead of â€˜servantsâ€™. The latter, he explained, are â€˜special peopleâ€™ - among them Moses, the prophet Elijah and the Virgin Mary - to whom God entrusts important missions. â€˜But all this is not enough, according to Jesus, to say who we are for Him,â€™ said Pope Francis.
Indeed, it takes â€˜something greater, which goes beyond goods and projects themselves: it takes friendshipâ€™. Friendship takes various forms depending on the age one goes through: it evolves as time advances. Pope Francis shared examples of these, set in the various moments of life. As children, it is expressed through the practice of offering friends â€˜our most beautiful toys and giftsâ€™; as teenagers by confiding to them â€˜our first secretsâ€™; as young people by offering friends â€˜loyaltyâ€™; as adults by sharing â€˜satisfactions and worriesâ€™; and as old people by sharing â€˜memoriesâ€™ and â€˜silencesâ€™.
The Holy Father then asked them to turn their thoughts to â€˜our friends, our friendsâ€™, thanking the Lord for their presence. He then invited the faithful gathered in St Peter's Square on today's spring day to carve out â€˜a space to think of themâ€™. A few moments of recollection followed.
Francis then explained that friendship â€˜is not the fruit of calculation, nor of compulsionâ€™, but is born instead from the spontaneity of recognising â€˜in the other something of usâ€™. In fact, if it is â€˜trueâ€™ it is capable of surviving even in the face of â€˜betrayalâ€™, just â€˜as Jesus shows us when he says to Judas, who betrays him with a kiss, â€™Friend, that is why you are here! (Mt 26:50),â€™ the Pontiff continued. â€˜A true friend does not abandon you, not even when you make a mistake: he corrects you, perhaps rebukes you, but he forgives you and does not abandon youâ€™.
From the passage from the Gospel according to John commented on this morning, it is understood that for Jesus â€˜we are just that, friendsâ€™; that is, â€˜dear people beyond all merit and all expectation, to whom he extends his hand and offers his loveâ€™.
At the end of the speech that preceded the Regina Caeli, Pope Francis addressed some questions to those listening, useful for integrating the Word with the life of each person. â€˜What face does the Lord have for me? The face of a friend or a stranger?â€™ But also: â€˜Do I feel loved by Him as a loved one?â€™. Finally, he asked for Mary's support so that we might â€˜grow in friendship with her Son and spread it around usâ€™.

author: 406 MT Sports
title: Claire Rutherford wins third Gatorade girls cross country award - NewsBreak
text:
By 406 MT Sports ,
1 hours ago CHICAGO â€” Bozeman Gallatin senior Claire Rutherford has been named the 2024-25 Gatorade Montana Girls Cross Country Player of the Year. According to a press release issued Thursday, Rutherford is the first Raptor to win the award and has now earned the honor three years in a row. She joins fellow Gallatin athlete Cadence Lundgren (volleyball) as current fall sport award winners. Read full article
Read in NewsBreak 1

text:

author: Noor Ul Ain
title: Pakistan govt notifies 25% increase in salaries and pensions - Daily Times
text: The government has announced a 15 percent pension increase, along with a 25% ad hoc relief for all federal employees in grades 1 through 16 and 20% for grades 17 through 22, effective from July 1, 2024. According to the notification, employees in grades 1 to 16 will see a 25% salary increase, while officers in grades 17 to 22 will receive a 20% raise. These adjustments will be applied to the employeesâ€™ basic pay starting from July 1, 2024. Moreover, federal government retirees will benefit from a 15% increase in their pensions, applicable to both civil and armed forces retirees. Employees retiring on or after July 1, 2024, will also be eligible for this pension increase. The ad-hoc relief allowance for 2024 will be subject to income tax, admissible during leave and the entire period of LPR except during extraordinary leave. It will not be considered part of emoluments for calculating pension/gratuity and recovery of house rent. It will not be available to employees during their posting/deputation abroad but will be admissible to employees upon their repatriation from posting/deputation abroad at the rate and amount that would have been admissible had they not been posted abroad.

author: Admin
title: BREAKING: Northwestern parts ways with director of football performance Jay Hooten - Top World News Today
text: Northwesternâ€™s slew of staff changes has found its way off the field. The â€˜Cats are moving on from director of football performance Jay Hooten, Matt Fortuna reported Thursday afternoon. Sources: Northwestern has parted ways with OC Mike Bajakian, special teams coordinator/TEs coach Jeff Genyk and director of sports performance for football Jay Hooten. â€” Matt Fortuna (@Matt_Fortuna) [December 28, 2023] Hooten had been with the Wildcats since 2009 before being elevated to director of football performance in 2011, where he oversaw NUâ€™s strength, speed and conditioning training. His release is the third move made by David Braun since the conclusion of Northwesternâ€™s season, as NU parted ways with offensive coordinator Mike Bajakian and special teams coordinator/tight ends coach Jeff Genyk as well. This past summer, Hooten was named in lawsuit filed by former player Lloyd Yates. In the complaint, which was filed in late July, Yates alleged that Hooten informed the team that Yates had â€œratted them outâ€ for partying before a workout, and Yates was subsequently â€œranâ€ by his teammates after the workout. Before arriving to Evanston, Hooten spent six years at Ohio State, serving as an assistant for the Buckeyes strength and conditioning program during their 2002 BCS National Championship season. An Ohio native, Hooten played high school football with current NU safeties coach Matt MacPherson.
